sn12.20:1.2.pli: “Paṭiccasamuppādañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi paṭiccasamuppanne ca dhamme.
sn12.20:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you dependent origination and dependently originated phenomena.
sn12.20:1.2.comm: Dependent origination is the process, dependently originated phenomena are the products.

sn12.20:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.20:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.20:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.20:2.2.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.

sn12.20:2.3.pli: Uppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ anuppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ, ṭhitāva sā dhātu dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatā idappaccayatā.
sn12.20:2.3.eng: Whether Realized Ones arise or not, this law of nature persists, this regularity of natural principles, this surety of natural principles, specific conditionality.
sn12.20:2.3.comm: The principles of the Dhamma are not impermanent, since they are not things that exist. Rather, they are laws of nature that describe a process or a pattern which is always observable, so it is always true to describe it in that way. At AN 3.136 the same idea applies to impermanence, suffering and not-self. Also see Poṭṭhapāda at DN 9:31.10. | For “surety” (niyāmatā) compare Rig Veda 4.3.9, “With truth I invoke the truth set down” (ṛtena ṛtaṁ niyatam). It is related to the idea that the stream-enterer “steps into the sure path”, i.e. enters the noble eightfold path, and is therefore “sure” in the sense of confident, and “sure” in the sense of being bound for awakening.

sn12.20:2.4.eng: A Realized One awakens to this and comprehends it,

sn12.20:2.5.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti.
sn12.20:2.5.eng: then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.

sn12.20:2.7.eng: ‘Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death.’

sn12.20:3.1.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth …

sn12.20:3.2.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence …

sn12.20:3.3.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping …

sn12.20:3.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving …

sn12.20:3.5.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling …

sn12.20:3.6.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact …

sn12.20:3.7.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields …

sn12.20:3.8.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form …

sn12.20:3.9.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness …

sn12.20:3.10.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

sn12.20:3.11.pli: uppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ anuppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ, ṭhitāva sā dhātu dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatā idappaccayatā.
sn12.20:3.11.eng: Whether Realized Ones arise or not, this law of nature persists, this regularity of natural principles, this surety of natural principles, specific conditionality.

sn12.20:3.12.eng: A Realized One awakens to this and comprehends it,

sn12.20:3.13.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti.
sn12.20:3.13.eng: then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.

sn12.20:3.16.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, yā tatra tathatā avitathatā anaññathatā idappaccayatā—
sn12.20:3.16.eng: So the fact that this is real, not unreal, not otherwise; the specific conditionality of it:

sn12.20:3.17.comm: This phrase is also at SN 12.1:2.14. Note that there is no corresponding “dependent cessation”. The ending of dependent origination is Nibbāna, extinguishment.

sn12.20:4.1.eng: And what are the dependently originated phenomena?

sn12.20:4.2.pli: Jarāmaraṇaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammaṃ.
sn12.20:4.2.eng: Old age and death are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

sn12.20:4.3.pli: Jāti, bhikkhave, aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.

sn12.20:4.4.pli: Bhavo, bhikkhave, anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno khayadhammo vayadhammo virāgadhammo nirodhadhammo.

sn12.20:4.13.pli: avijjā, bhikkhave, aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.
sn12.20:4.13.eng: Ignorance is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

sn12.20:4.14.eng: These are called the dependently originated phenomena.

sn12.20:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa ‘ayañca paṭiccasamuppādo, ime ca paṭiccasamuppannā dhammā’ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti, so vata pubbantaṃ vā paṭidhāvissati:
sn12.20:5.1.eng: When a noble disciple has clearly seen with right wisdom this dependent origination and these dependently originated phenomena as they are, it will be quite impossible for them to turn back to the first beginning, thinking:

sn12.20:5.2.pli: ‘ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, nanu kho ahosiṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ nu kho ahosiṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, kathaṃ nu kho ahosiṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ hutvā kiṃ ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhānan’ti;
sn12.20:5.2.eng: ‘Did I exist in the past? Did I not exist in the past? What was I in the past? How was I in the past? After being what, what did I become in the past?’
sn12.20:5.2.comm: These are called “irrational thoughts” at MN 2:7.3. These are ways of thinking driven by anxiety over the perpetuation or dissolution of the assumed Self.

sn12.20:5.3.eng: Or to turn forward to the final end, thinking:

sn12.20:5.4.pli: ‘bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, nanu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṃ, kathaṃ nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṃ, kiṃ hutvā kiṃ bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti;
sn12.20:5.4.eng: ‘Will I exist in the future? Will I not exist in the future? What will I be in the future? How will I be in the future? After being what, what will I become in the future?’

sn12.20:5.5.pli: etarahi vā paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ ajjhattaṃ kathaṅkathī bhavissati:
sn12.20:5.5.eng: Or to be undecided about the present, thinking:

sn12.20:5.6.pli: ‘ahaṃ nu khosmi, no nu khosmi, kiṃ nu khosmi, kathaṃ nu khosmi, ayaṃ nu kho satto kuto āgato, so kuhiṃ gamissatī’ti—
sn12.20:5.6.eng: ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This sentient being—where did it come from? And where will it go?’

sn12.20:5.9.pli: Tathā hi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa ayañca paṭiccasamuppādo ime ca paṭiccasamuppannā dhammā yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā”ti.
sn12.20:5.9.eng: Because that noble disciple has clearly seen with right wisdom this dependent origination and these dependently originated phenomena as they are.”

sn12.21:1.2.pli: “Dasabalasamannāgato, bhikkhave, tathāgato catūhi ca vesārajjehi samannāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti—
sn12.21:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a Realized One has ten powers and four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.
sn12.21:1.2.comm: The purpose of this discourse (and the next) seems to be to extol dependent origination as a special insight of the Buddha. But it does so artlessly, simply plonking down a series of teachings without connecting them in any way. Editors and translators have tried to smooth it over, but I translate as-is. | The ten powers (of a Realized One) are explained at MN 12:9.1, where they are followed by the four kinds of self-assurance (MN 12:22.1). The powers are found independently at AN 10.21 and AN 10.22, and are claimed by Anuruddha at SN 52.15–24. The four kinds of self-assurance are at AN 4.8. | The “divine wheel” (brahmacakka) is a synonym for the “wheel of the teaching” (dhammacakka). In Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 1.6, the same term refers to the circle of existence in which all things live.

sn12.21:1.3.pli: iti rūpaṃ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo,
sn12.21:1.3.eng: Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
sn12.21:1.3.comm: This is a recommended meditation (MN 10:38.4) leading to perfection (SN 12.23:1.4). In one place it exemplifies the Buddha’s teaching, but there it follows organically and is marked as quote (SN 22.78:2.2). Here it is simply pasted in after the previous passage. It does not offer an integration between the aggregates and dependent origination; they simply appear side by side.

sn12.21:1.4.pli: iti vedanā iti vedanāya samudayo iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo,
sn12.21:1.4.eng: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the disappearance of feeling.

sn12.21:1.5.pli: iti saññā iti saññāya samudayo iti saññāya atthaṅgamo,
sn12.21:1.5.eng: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the disappearance of perception.

sn12.21:1.6.pli: iti saṅkhārā iti saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo,
sn12.21:1.6.eng: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the disappearance of choices.

sn12.21:1.7.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn12.21:1.7.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the disappearance of consciousness.

sn12.21:1.8.pli: Iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati.
sn12.21:1.8.eng: When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.
sn12.21:1.8.comm: This is the abstract principle of dependent origination; see discussion at SN 12.37:2.2. Again there is no textual link with the previous passages.

sn12.21:1.9.pli: Imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.21:1.9.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

sn12.21:1.10.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

sn12.21:1.11.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.21:1.12.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.21:1.13.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.21:1.15.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

sn12.22:1.2.pli: “Dasabalasamannāgato, bhikkhave, tathāgato catūhi ca vesārajjehi samannāgato āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṃ nadati, brahmacakkaṃ pavatteti:
sn12.22:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a Realized One has ten powers and four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the divine wheel.

sn12.22:1.3.pli: ‘iti rūpaṃ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo,
sn12.22:1.3.eng: Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

sn12.22:1.4.pli: iti vedanā iti vedanāya samudayo iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo,
sn12.22:1.4.eng: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

sn12.22:1.5.pli: iti saññā iti saññāya samudayo iti saññāya atthaṅgamo,
sn12.22:1.5.eng: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.

sn12.22:1.6.pli: iti saṅkhārā iti saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo iti saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo,
sn12.22:1.6.eng: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.

sn12.22:1.7.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo.
sn12.22:1.7.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.

sn12.22:1.8.pli: Iti imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imassuppādā idaṃ uppajjati;
sn12.22:1.8.eng: When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.

sn12.22:1.9.pli: imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti imassa nirodhā idaṃ nirujjhati.
sn12.22:1.9.eng: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases. That is:

sn12.22:1.10.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

sn12.22:1.11.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn12.22:1.12.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn12.22:1.13.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

sn12.22:1.15.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn12.22:2.1.pli: Evaṃ svākkhāto, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo uttāno vivaṭo pakāsito chinnapilotiko.
sn12.22:2.1.eng: The teaching well-explained thus by me is clarified, revealed, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.
sn12.22:2.1.comm: “Stripped of patchwork” is ironic given that this is, in fact, a patchwork discourse. This passage appears at MN 22:42.1, where it has a meaningful context. The following section on arousing energy is another patchwork, this time of passages from elsewhere in the canon on arousing energy.

sn12.22:2.2.pli: Evaṃ svākkhāte kho, bhikkhave, mayā dhamme uttāne vivaṭe pakāsite chinnapilotike alameva saddhāpabbajitena kulaputtena vīriyaṃ ārabhituṃ:
sn12.22:2.2.eng: In this teaching thus well-explained, it is quite enough for a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith to rouse up energy.
sn12.22:2.2.comm: This sentence is not entirely coherent. The opening phrase is normally followed by “those who”, while alameva (“quite enough”) follows the accusative, not the locative.

sn12.22:2.3.pli: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ. Yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ, na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
sn12.22:2.3.eng: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and tendons remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’
sn12.22:2.3.comm: Also at AN 2.5:1.4, SN 21.3:3.6, SN 12.22:2.3, and MN 70:27.6.

sn12.22:3.1.pli: Dukkhaṃ, bhikkhave, kusīto viharati vokiṇṇo pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi, mahantañca sadatthaṃ parihāpeti.
sn12.22:3.1.eng: A lazy person lives in suffering, mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities, neglecting their heart’s great goal.
sn12.22:3.1.comm: Elsewhere we find, “in a well explained teaching and training a lazy person lives in suffering” at AN 1.325:1.1, and “mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities” at AN 3.40:2.11.

sn12.22:3.2.pli: Āraddhavīriyo ca kho, bhikkhave, sukhaṃ viharati pavivitto pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi, mahantañca sadatthaṃ paripūreti.
sn12.22:3.2.eng: But an energetic person lives happily, secluded from bad, unskillful qualities, fulfilling their heart’s great goal.

sn12.22:3.3.pli: Na, bhikkhave, hīnena aggassa patti hoti.
sn12.22:3.3.eng: The best isn’t reached by the worst.

sn12.22:3.4.pli: Aggena ca kho, bhikkhave, aggassa patti hoti.
sn12.22:3.4.eng: The best is reached by the best.

sn12.22:3.5.eng: This spiritual life is the cream, mendicants, and the Teacher is before you.

sn12.22:3.6.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, vīriyaṃ ārabhatha appattassa pattiyā, anadhigatassa adhigamāya, asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
sn12.22:3.6.eng: So you should rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized, thinking:

sn12.22:3.7.pli: ‘Evaṃ no ayaṃ amhākaṃ pabbajjā avañjhā bhavissati saphalā saudrayā.
sn12.22:3.7.eng: ‘In this way our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.
sn12.22:3.7.comm: Almost the same as AN 7.72:17.2 ff.

sn12.22:3.8.pli: Yesañca mayaṃ paribhuñjāma cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ tesaṃ te kārā amhesu mahapphalā bhavissanti mahānisaṃsā’ti—
sn12.22:3.8.eng: And the services of those whose robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick we enjoy shall be very fruitful and beneficial for them.’

sn12.22:3.10.pli: Attatthaṃ vā hi, bhikkhave, sampassamānena alameva appamādena sampādetuṃ;
sn12.22:3.10.eng: Considering what is good for yourself, mendicants, is quite enough for you to persist with diligence.

sn12.22:3.11.pli: paratthaṃ vā hi, bhikkhave, sampassamānena alameva appamādena sampādetuṃ;
sn12.22:3.11.eng: Considering what is good for others is quite enough for you to persist with diligence.

sn12.22:3.12.pli: ubhayatthaṃ vā hi, bhikkhave, sampassamānena alameva appamādena sampādetun”ti.
sn12.22:3.12.eng: Considering what is good for both is quite enough for you to persist with diligence.”

sn12.23:1.1.comm: This discourse uniquely links the conditional arising of suffering with the conditional unfolding of the path, showing that liberation is not possible without suffering.

sn12.23:1.2.pli: “Jānato ahaṃ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
sn12.23:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see.
sn12.23:1.2.comm: The “ending of defilements” (āsavānaṁ khayaṁ) is a common sutta term for arahantship. | “Knowing and seeing” refers to the penetrating insight that arises from meditative immersion (samādhi, eg. AN 5.168:2.2, AN 10.2:2.3, SN 12.23:6.18, DN 2:83.1). | The opening is shared with SN 22.101, SN 56.25, MN 2, and Iti 102.

sn12.23:1.3.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato kiṃ passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti?
sn12.23:1.3.eng: For one who knows and sees what?

sn12.23:1.4.pli: Iti rūpaṃ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo,
sn12.23:1.4.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

sn12.23:1.8.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamoti.
sn12.23:1.8.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

sn12.23:1.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
sn12.23:1.9.eng: The ending of the defilements is for one who knows and sees this.

sn12.23:2.1.pli: Yampissa taṃ, bhikkhave, khayasmiṃ khaye ñāṇaṃ, tampi saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:2.1.eng: I say that this knowledge of ending has a vital condition, it doesn’t lack a vital condition.
sn12.23:2.1.comm: An upanisā is a conditional factor that is both necessary and strongly conducive. It functions as a contraction of upanissaya (“rely on”). Elsewhere, saupanisa is used of the seven path factors as “vital conditions” for right immersion (SN 45.28:1.2, MN 117:2.1). Pali upanisā is also found in the distinct sense “sitting close” to a teacher (AN 3.67:6.7). | It is not clear if upanisā is the same as the Sanskrit upaniṣad, for which the oldest sense is “correspondence, equivalence”, referring to the secret links between things (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 10.4.5.1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.9.26, 4.2.1; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 3.11.3, 8.8.4; Taittirīya Upaniṣad 1.11.4, 2.9.1). These equivalences are explained in the esoteric teachings that themselves came to be known as Upaniṣads.

sn12.23:2.2.pli: Kā ca, bhikkhave, khaye ñāṇassa upanisā?

sn12.23:2.3.comm: “Freedom” here is the liberation from defilements, namely arahantship itself. The arahant reviews their freedom, which is the “knowledge of ending”.

sn12.23:2.4.pli: Vimuttimpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:2.4.eng: I say that freedom has a vital condition, it doesn’t lack a vital condition.

sn12.23:2.6.comm: “Dispassion” (virāga) has a dual sense in Pali: a state where lust (rāga) is absent, and the process of defilements “fading away”, which leans on the sense of rāga as “dye” (eg. the “fading away of ignorance” at SN 12.51:9.4).

sn12.23:2.7.pli: Virāgampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:2.7.eng: I say that dispassion has a vital condition.

sn12.23:2.9.comm: “Disillusionment” (nibbidā) is the turning away in disappointment upon realizing that one cannot get what one wants (MN 50:31.15, SN 35.240:1.8).

sn12.23:2.10.pli: Nibbidampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:2.10.eng: I say that disillusionment has a vital condition.

sn12.23:2.12.eng: You should say: ‘Truly knowing and seeing.’
sn12.23:2.12.comm: This is the insight of stream-entry.

sn12.23:2.13.pli: Yathābhūtañāṇadassanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:2.13.eng: I say that truly knowing and seeing has a vital condition.

sn12.23:2.15.comm: “Immersion” (samādhi) is a general term for the absorptions (jhāna) and other profound meditations free of the hindrances. It is an integrated emotional state of elevated consciousness, during which the mind is extremely bright and powerful. For a meditator with right view, the empowered mind emerging from immersion naturally inclines towards insight into the suffering of holding on and the bliss of letting go.

sn12.23:2.16.pli: Samādhimpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:2.16.eng: I say that immersion has a vital condition.

sn12.23:3.2.comm: Because immersion is an emotional release, its primary condition is deep, pervasive, lasting, and subtle bliss or pleasure (sukha). It cannot be realized with purely neutral feeling.

sn12.23:3.3.pli: Sukhampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:3.3.eng: I say that bliss has a vital condition.

sn12.23:3.5.comm: “Tranquility” is a settled and serene body and mind, as activities or energies become stilled through the process of meditation.

sn12.23:3.6.pli: Passaddhimpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:3.6.eng: I say that tranquility has a vital condition.

sn12.23:3.8.comm: “Rapture” (pīti) is a heightened emotional response to happiness or joy. Minor forms appear as tingling or thrill, and it deepens into a pervasive spiritual sense of elevation or uplift in meditation.

sn12.23:3.9.pli: Pītimpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:3.9.eng: I say that rapture has a vital condition.

sn12.23:3.11.comm: “Joy” (pāmojja) is the upwelling of happiness connected with wholesome things, such as hearing the Dhamma (MN 33:23.2), or reflecting on one’s progress (MN 7:11.1, MN 40:8.2) or ethical purity (AN 10.2:1.6).

sn12.23:3.12.pli: Pāmojjampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:3.12.eng: I say that joy has a vital condition.

sn12.23:3.14.comm: “Faith” inspires the courage to progress. It is a “grounded faith” based on experience, and tested through the path (MN 47:16.1).

sn12.23:3.15.pli: Saddhampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:3.15.eng: I say that faith has a vital condition.

sn12.23:4.2.comm: Someone afflicted by suffering looks about in despair to find anyone who can help. When they hear the Buddha or a disciple speaking about suffering, faith arises (AN 6.63:42.3). | With this link, the discourse reveals the connection between the path to freedom and dependent origination. Suffering is the condition into which we have been born, but the experience of suffering is also the stimulus we need to seek freedom.

sn12.23:4.3.pli: Dukkhampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:4.3.eng: I say that suffering has a vital condition.

sn12.23:4.5.comm: From here the discourse proceeds back through the standard links in reverse order.

sn12.23:4.6.pli: Jātimpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:4.6.eng: I say that rebirth has a vital condition.

sn12.23:4.9.pli: Bhavampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:4.9.eng: I say that continued existence has a vital condition.

sn12.23:4.12.pli: Upādānampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:4.12.eng: I say that grasping has a vital condition.

sn12.23:4.15.pli: Taṇhampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṃ vadāmi, no anupanisaṃ.
sn12.23:4.15.eng: I say that craving has a vital condition.

sn12.23:5.4.eng: You should say: ‘The six sense fields.’ …

sn12.23:5.8.pli: Saṅkhārepāhaṃ, bhikkhave, saupanise vadāmi, no anupanise.
sn12.23:5.8.eng: I say that choices have a vital condition, they don’t lack a vital condition.

sn12.23:5.9.eng: And what is the vital condition for choices?

sn12.23:6.1.eng: So, mendicants: ignorance is the vital condition for choices.
sn12.23:6.1.comm: The syntax is subtly different to the standard sequence (SN 12.2:2.2). There, the initial term is ablative, which conveys the causal sense and might be literally rendered, “Due to the ignorance dependency, choices”. Here the two terms are both nominative, so there is no causal sense in the nouns. We must assume, then, that the causal sense is supplied by the implicit verb hoti in the pregnant sense “bring about, beget, yield”. A literal rendering might be, “The ignorance vital condition begets choices.”

sn12.23:6.2.eng: Choices are the vital condition for consciousness.

sn12.23:6.3.eng: Consciousness is the vital condition for name and form.

sn12.23:6.4.eng: Name and form are the vital conditions for the six sense fields.

sn12.23:6.5.eng: The six sense fields are the vital conditions for contact.

sn12.23:6.6.eng: Contact is the vital condition for feeling.

sn12.23:6.7.eng: Feeling is the vital condition for craving.

sn12.23:6.8.eng: Craving is the vital condition for grasping.

sn12.23:6.9.eng: Grasping is the vital condition for continued existence.

sn12.23:6.10.eng: Continued existence is the vital condition for rebirth.

sn12.23:6.11.eng: Rebirth is the vital condition for suffering.

sn12.23:6.12.eng: Suffering is the vital condition for faith.

sn12.23:6.13.eng: Faith is the vital condition for joy.

sn12.23:6.14.eng: Joy is the vital condition for rapture.

sn12.23:6.15.eng: Rapture is the vital condition for tranquility.

sn12.23:6.16.eng: Tranquility is the vital condition for bliss.

sn12.23:6.17.eng: Bliss is the vital condition for immersion.

sn12.23:6.18.eng: Immersion is the vital condition for truly knowing and seeing.

sn12.23:6.19.eng: Truly knowing and seeing is the vital condition for disillusionment.

sn12.23:6.20.eng: Disillusionment is the vital condition for dispassion.

sn12.23:6.21.eng: Dispassion is the vital condition for freedom.

sn12.23:6.22.eng: Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.

sn12.23:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti. Pabbatakandarapadarasākhāparipūrā kusobbhe paripūrenti. Kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti. Mahāsobbhā paripūrā kunnadiyo paripūrenti. Kunnadiyo paripūrā mahānadiyo paripūrenti. Mahānadiyo paripūrā mahāsamuddaṃ paripūrenti.
sn12.23:7.1.eng: It’s like when the heavens rain heavily on a mountain top, and the water flows downhill to fill the hollows, crevices, and creeks. As they become full, they fill up the pools. The pools fill up the lakes, the lakes fill up the streams, and the streams fill up the rivers. And as the rivers become full, they fill up the ocean.
sn12.23:7.1.comm: This simile is also found in SN 55.38, AN 3.95, AN 4.147, AN 10.61, and AN 10.62. Compare Kaṭha Upaniṣad 4.15.

sn12.23:8.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṃ viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇūpanisaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpūpanisaṃ saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṃ upādānaṃ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṃ dukkhaṃ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṃ sukhaṃ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṃ khaye ñāṇan”ti.
sn12.23:8.1.eng: In the same way, ignorance is the vital condition for choices. … Freedom is the vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”
